tn.text: This word is used here to mark a break in the main storyline. Here the narrator tells us why the gates of Jericho are closed and locked up.

tn.ref: I have delivered Jericho into your hand, its king, and its trained soldiers
tn.text: Yahweh is telling Joshua that he will certainly do this by saying that he has already done it. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_pastforfuture]])
This means "into your control" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
God continues telling Joshua what the people must do.

tn.ref: You must do this for six days
tn.text: "You must do this once each day for six days"

tn.ref: Seven priests must carry seven trumpets of rams' horns before the ark
tn.text: The seven priests are to march in front of other priests who are carrying the ark and marching around the city.
God continues telling Joshua what the people must do.

tn.ref: they must sound a long blast with the ram's horn ... of the trumpet
tn.text: The word "they" refers to the seven priests. The "ram's horn" and "trumpet" refer to the trumpets of rams' horns that the priests were blowing in [[:en:bible:notes:jos:06:03|6:4]].
"the outer wall of the city" or "the wall surrounding the city"
This is Joshua's father. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: Take up the ark of the covenant
tn.text: "Pick up the ark of the covenant"
Possible meanings are 1) "in obedience to Yahweh" or 2) "in front of Yahweh's ark" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: they gave a blast on the trumpets
tn.text: "they sounded the trumpets loudly" or "the priests blew into the ram's horn trumpets"

tn.ref: The ark of the covenant of Yahweh followed after them
tn.text: It can be stated clearly that there were people carrying the ark. AT: "The priests who were carrying the ark of the covenant of Yahweh followed after them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: No sound must leave your mouths
tn.text: Sound leaving someone's mouth refers to that person's speaking or shouting. AT: "Do not yell or speak" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Joshua had commanded the people before they started walking around the city. AT: "Joshua had commanded the people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_events]])
"7 priests ... 7 trumpets" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
This means that they blew into their trumpets, causing them to make loud noises, multiple times. AT: "continually sounded the trumpets loudly" or "blew into the ram's horn trumpets continually"
the next day (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_ordinal]])
Israel marched around Jericho once every day.
"6 days" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
This refers to the people of Israel.

tn.ref: gave a blast with the trumpets
tn.text: "sounded the trumpets loudly" or "blew into the ram's horn trumpets"
Joshua is saying that Yahweh will definitely give them the city by saying that he has already given it to them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_pastforfuture]])
The word "you" refers to the entire nation of Israel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
Joshua continues speaking to the people of Israel.

tn.ref: The city and all that is in it will be set apart to Yahweh for destruction
tn.text: This can be stated with an active form. AT: "You must set apart to Yahweh the city and all that is in it for destruction" or "You must set apart to Yahweh the city and all that is in it by destroying it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: be on guard about taking the things
tn.text: Being careful is spoken of as if they are to guard themselves. "Be careful that you do not take the things" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: you will bring trouble on it
tn.text: Doing something that makes bad things to happen to the city is spoken of as bringing trouble on it. AT: "you will cause bad things to happen to it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
a collection of things set apart for the worship of Yahweh

tn.ref: the people gave a great shout
tn.text: "the people of Israel shouted"
"sounded the trumpets loudly" or "blew into the ram's horn trumpets"

tn.ref: by the edge of the sword
tn.text: Although many of the people of Israel used swords, this may refer to a violent attack or battle in general. AT: "with their sharp swords" or "in battle" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
The word "they" refers to the Israelite soldiers. It does not refer only to the two young men who brought Rahab and her family out of the city.
The word "She" refers to Rahab and represents her descendants. AT: "Her descendants live in Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"now" or "even today." Rahab's descendants are still living in Israel as the original writer writes this story.

tn.ref: Cursed is the man in Yahweh's sight who rebuilds
tn.text: Being cursed in Yahweh's sight represents being cursed by Yahweh. AT: "May Yahweh curse the man who rebuilds" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: At the cost of his firstborn son, he will lay the foundation
tn.text: The consequence of a man laying a new foundation for Jericho is that his firstborn son would die. This is spoken of as if it were a cost that the man would pay. AT: "If he lays the foundation, he will lose his firstborn son" or "If he lays the foundation, his firstborn son will die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: at the cost of his youngest son, he will set up its gates
tn.text: The consequence of a man setting up new gates for Jericho is that his youngest son would die. This is spoken of as if it were a cost that the man would pay. AT: "If he sets up its gates, he will lose his youngest son" or "If he sets up it gates, his youngest son will die" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: his fame spread throughout the land
tn.text: This refers to Joshua's fame, not Yahweh's. Becoming known among the people throughout the land is spoken of as if his fame spread. AT: "Joshua became famous throughout the land" or "people throughout the land learned about Joshua"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
